case_name: Narain Singh and others v. Tehl Singh and Arjan Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 223 and 224 of 1961 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 223 224 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and decree dated April 25, 1956 of Punjab High Court in Civil Regular Second Appeals Nos. 158 and 159 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated April 25, 1956. of the Punjab High Court in Civil Regular Second Appeals Nos. 158 and 159 of 1949 respectively.

facts.text: Dispute relates to agricultural lands in village Umri Ana, tehsil Zira, District Ferozepore, Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: These appeal arise out of two suits relating to certian agricultural lands situate in village Umri Ana, tehsil Zira District Ferozepore in the Punjab.

facts.text: Dispute concerns right to inherit estate of Harnam Singh, grandson of Kahan Singh, the last male holder.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute relates to the right to inherit the estate of one Hamam Singh who was the last male holder.

facts.text: Harnam Singh died leaving surviving two daughters Mst. Tejo and Mst. Gejo and no male lineal descendants.

anchor.surface_text: Harnam Singh grandson of Kahan Singh died leaving him surviving two daughters Mst. Tejo and Mst. Gejo and numbermale lineal descendant.

facts.text: Property of Harnam Singh devolved upon his two daughters in equal shares.

anchor.surface_text: The property of Harnam Singh devolved upon his two daughters in equal shares.

facts.text: Mst. Tejo died without issue.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Mst. Tejo without issue the entire estate was entered in the name of Mst. Gejo

facts.text: Entire estate entered in name of Mst. Gejo by revenue authorities after Tejo's death.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Mst. Tejo without issue the entire estate was entered in the name of Mst. Gejo by the revenue authorities.

facts.text: Mst. Gejo died in 1942 without leaving any issue.

anchor.surface_text: Mst. Gejo also died in 1942 without leaving any issue surviving her.

facts.text: On September 6, 1945, Assistant Collector directed entire estate be entered in name of Narain Singh s/o Dasaundha Singh and Bakshish Singh, Ajaib Singh, Mukhtar Singh s/o Ramji Singh (plaintiffs).

anchor.surface_text: By order dated September 6, 1945 the Assistant Collector directed that the entire estate be entered in the name of Narain Singh s o Dasaundha Singh and Bakshish Singh, Ajaib Singh and Mukhtar Singh sons of Ramji Singh-who will hereinafter be referred to companylectively as the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Collector of Ferozepore set aside Assistant Collector's order and directed estate to Tehl Singh and Arjan Singh s/o Mangal Singh (defendants).

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Collector of Ferozepore the order of the Assistant Collector was set aside and the estate was directed to be entered in the names of Tehl Singh and Arjan Singh sons of Mangal Singh--who will hereinafter be referred to companylecti- vely as the defendants.

facts.text: Commissioner of the Division confirmed the order of the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of the Division companyfirmed the order of the Collector.

facts.text: Plaintiffs (descendants of Ghuda Singh) instituted Suit No. 9/1947 in Court of Subordinate Judge, Zira for possession of Harnam Singh's estate barring 8 Kanals 11 Marlas Khasra No. 325.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs who are the descendants of Ghuda Singh then instituted suit No. 9/1947 in the Court of the Subordinate judge, Zira for a decree for possession of the estate of Harnam Singh, barring a small area of 8 Kanals and 11 MarlasKhasra No. 325--which was in their possession.

facts.text: Defendants (descendants of Wazir Singh) commenced Suit No. 13/1947 for possession of Khasra No. 325 against plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants who are the descendants of Wazir Singh in their turn companymenced an action  Suit No. 13/1947  for possession of Khasra No. 325 against the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Ghuda Singh was adopted some time before 1856 by Bhan Singh, his maternal uncle. This is common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that Ghuda Singh was adopted some time before 1856 by Bhan Singh, his maternal uncle.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claim that notwithstanding adoption of Ghuda Singh, his descendants not excluded from inheritance in natural family per Zamindara Riwaj-i-am.

anchor.surface_text: It was the case of the plaintiffs that numberwithstanding the adoption of Ghuda Singh by his maternal uncle Bhan Singh, Ghuda Singhs descendants were number excluded from inheritance to the estate of a member in the natural family of Ghuda Singh

facts.text: Defendants claim that in Ferozepore District, adoption is formal and adopted son excluded from natural family inheritance.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants, on the other hand, claimed that in the District of Ferozepore every adoption in a Hindu family is formal and according to the Riwaj-i-am of the District an adopted son is excluded from the right to inherit in his natural family.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held ceremonies of adoption performed, Ghuda Singh ceased to be member of natural family, plaintiffs cannot inherit.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate judge held that all ceremonies relating to adoption were performed and Ghuda Singh ceased to be a member of the family of his natural father according to the custom prevailing in the District and the plaintiffs who were the descendants of Ghuda Singh companyld number inherit the estate of Hamir Singh.

facts.text: District Court, Ferozepore held adopted son has right to inherit collaterally only in adoptive family, not natural.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the District Court, Ferozepore held that in the case of Jats of Ferozepore District by special custom prevailing in the District, the adopted son bad the right to inherit companylaterally in the family of his adoptive father only and companyld number inherit companylaterally in his natural fathers family.

facts.text: Punjab High Court set aside District Court decree, presumed customary appointment of heir, not formal adoption; plaintiffs entitled.

anchor.surface_text: In second appeal the High Court of Punjab set aside the decree passed by the District Court. In the view- of the High Court the record disclosed numberevidence that the adoption of Ghuda Singh made by his maternal uncle Bhan Singh was formal ... plaintiffs, as grandsons in the male line of Ghuda Singh, were entitled to inherit the estate of Hamir Singh.

facts.text: Two suits consolidated for trial.

anchor.surface_text: The two suits were companysolidated for trial.

facts.text: Plaintiffs are descendants of Ghuda Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs who are the descendants of Ghuda Singh

facts.text: Defendants are descendants of Wazir Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants who are the descendants of Wazir Singh

facts.text: On death of Hamir Singh, estate initially entered in names of his three sons, but Ghuda Singh's name removed per patwari report on May 28, 1884.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from that extract that on the death of Hamir Singh the estate was in the first instance entered in the names of his three sons. But Salig Ram, Patwari of the village, made a report on May 28, 1884 that Kahan Singh and Chuhar Singh

facts.text: Assistant Collector ordered lands entered in names of Kahan Singh and Chuhar Singh, removing Ghuda Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On that report the Assistant Collector ordered that the lands be entered in the names of Kahan Singh and Chuhar Singh and that the name of Ghuda Singh be removed from the mutation entry

facts.text: High Court granted certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate of fitness granted by the High Court, these two appeals are preferred by the defendants.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah J. on February 12, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. February 12. The judgment of the companyrt was delivered by SHAH J.

facts.text: Supreme Court held general custom per Rattigan's Digest applies; no inconsistency with Riwaj-i-am for collateral inheritance.

anchor.surface_text: But we are number companycerned with that inconsistency in this case. It is sufficient to observe that in Art. 48 of Rattigans Digest, it is recorded that an heir appointed in the manner described  an adopted son  does number thereby lose his right to succeed to property in his natural family

facts.text: Instances relied by defendants do not establish departure from general custom.

anchor.surface_text: But this instance of exclusion of Ghuda Singh from the right to participate in the estate of his father is companysistent with the statement of custom recorded in Rattigans Digest.

facts.text: High Court view affirmed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to disagree with the view so expressed.

The dispute between the parties has to be resolved by applying the customary law applicable to the parties, because s. 5 of the Punjab Laws Act, 1872 which governs the parties provides that In questions regarding succession, special property of females, betrothal and marriage, divorce, dower, adoption, guardianship, minority, bastardy, family relations, wills, legacies, gifts, partition, or any religious usage or insti-

concepts.interpretation: Rule of decision in matters of succession, adoption etc. is first any applicable custom not contrary to justice, equity or good conscience, failing which personal law (Hindu or Muhammadan).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the matter of adoption is to be found in Rattigans Digest of Civil law for the Punjab, 13. Edn. p. 572 Article 48 An heir appointed in the manner abo

concepts.unlisted_description: Governs application of custom vs personal law in succession and adoption.

anchor.surface_text: In Daya Ram v. Sohel Singh 1 , Rober son, J., at P. 410 in dealing with the true effect of s. 5 observed In all cases it appears to me under this Act, it lies upon the person asserting that he is ruled in regard to a particular matter by custom, to prove that he is so governed, and not by personal law, and further, to prove what the particular custom is.

concepts.interpretation: Party asserting governance by custom over personal law bears the burden to prove the custom exists and its content.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: A similar view was expressed in Kanshi Ram V. Situ  3 , and Rahmat v. Ziledar  4 . In the last mentioned case it was stated Under the general custom o

concepts.unlisted_description: Under Punjab Laws Act s.5, claimant must prove custom applies.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant general custom which is applicable in the matter of adoption is to be found in Rattigans Digest of Civil law for the Punjab, 13. Edn. p. 572 Article 48 An heir appointed in the manner above described ordinarily does not thereby lose his right to succeed to property in his natural family, as against collaterals,

concepts.interpretation: Customary appointed heir (adopted son) retains right to inherit collaterally in natural family, but not in presence of natural brothers.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ld only be by chundawand, if that was the prevalent rule of the family. The Nipals, Rajputs, Arains, Moghals, Sayyads, Gujjars and Muhammadan Jats sta

concepts.unlisted_description: General Punjab custom on inheritance rights of appointed heir in natural family.

anchor.surface_text: Article 49 Nor, on the other hand, does the heir acquire a right to succeed to the collateral relatives of the person who appoints him, where no formal adoption has taken place, inasmuch as the relationship established between him and the appointer is a purely personal one.

concepts.interpretation: Appointed heir does not acquire collateral inheritance rights in adoptive family without formal adoption; relationship is personal.
concepts.unlisted_description: Limits rights in adoptive family under general custom.

anchor.surface_text: Article 52 sets out the rights of the adopted son. It states The appointed heir succeeds to all the rights and interests held or enjoyed by the appointer and, semble, would succeed equally with a natural son subsequently born.

concepts.interpretation: Appointed heir succeeds fully to appointer's estate, equally with later natural sons.
concepts.unlisted_description: Rights of appointed heir in adoptive family.

anchor.surface_text: Question 76--Does an adopted son retain his right to inherit from his natural father ? Can he inherit from his natural father if the natural father dies without other sons Answer-All agree that the adopted son cannot inherit from his natural father, except as for as regards such share of the property as would come to his adoptive father as a collateral.

concepts.interpretation: Adopted son cannot inherit directly from natural father, except via adoptive father's collateral share; some variation by tribe.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: rty as would devolve upon his adoptive father as a companylateral  of the adopted sons natural father . It is to be numbericed that the question was d

concepts.unlisted_description: Local custom on adopted son's inheritance from natural father.

anchor.surface_text: Question 77-Describe the rights of an adopted son to inherit from his adoptive father. What is the effect of the subsequent birth of legitimate sons to the adoptive father ? Will the adopted son take equal shares with them ? ... Answer-An adopted son has exactly the same rights of inheritance from his adoptive father as a natural legitimate son.

concepts.interpretation: Adopted son inherits equally from adoptive father as natural son; got/tribe issues for some groups.
concepts.unlisted_description: Local custom on adopted son's inheritance from adoptive father.

anchor.surface_text: When there is conflict between the general custom stated in Rattigans Digest of Customary Law and the Riwaj-i-am which applies to a particular area it has been held by this Court that the latter prevails. In Jai Kapur v. Sher Singh 1 , it was observed There is, therefore, an initial presumption of correctness as regards the entries in the Riwaj-i-am

concepts.interpretation: Riwaj-i-am entries presumed correct and prevail over general custom (Rattigan) in case of conflict, rebuttable by proof, weaker if adversely affects females.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: answer it was recorded that to the estate which would devolve upon his adoptive father as a companylateral of his natural father he has a right of inh

concepts.unlisted_description: Local Riwaj-i-am prevails over general custom prima facie.

anchor.surface_text: the adoption was a customary appointment of an heir and not a formal adoption under the Hindu Law and that there was overwhelming authority in favour of the proposition that by reason of a customary adoption the adopted son and his descendants were not excluded from the right to inherit to collaterals in the natural family.

concepts.interpretation: Customary adoption (appointment of heir) is personal, does not sever ties with natural family for collateral succession, unlike formal Hindu adoption.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: as for as regards such share of the property as would companye to his adoptive father as a companylateral. Sodhis however say that he can inherit his

concepts.unlisted_description: Punjab Zamindara custom distinguishing from formal adoption.

anchor.surface_text: not a formal adoption under the Hindu Law

concepts.interpretation: Formal adoption transplants son completely, excluding from natural family; not applicable here as presumed customary.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bindra contended that in any event there is clear evidence of instances of devolution of property in the family of the parties indicating that a son adopted in another family was totally excluded from inheritance in the natural family. Counsel relied upon Ext. D-5 an extract from the register of mutations

concepts.interpretation: Custom proved or departed from by clear, consistent instances; defendants' instances consistent with general custom, do not rebut.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the family of the parties indicating that a son adopted in another family was totally excluded from inheritance in the natural family. Counsel relied

concepts.unlisted_description: Custom established or rebutted by proven instances of practice.

anchor.surface_text: when Bishno contracted a Karewa marriage according to the custom prevalent in the community, the estate held by her was entered in the name of Rura Singh and Bhola Singh sons of Kahan Singh.

concepts.interpretation: Customary remarriage (Karewa) divests daughter's estate to collaterals.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: companymunity, the estate held by her was entered in the name of Rura Singh and Bhola Singh sons of Kahan Singh. In the register of mutations Ext. R

concepts.unlisted_description: Punjab custom affecting inheritance on widow/daughter remarriage.

anchor.surface_text: The inheritance would only be by chundawand, if that was the prevalent rule of the family.

concepts.interpretation: Per stirpes inheritance system if prevalent.
concepts.unlisted_description: Customary mode of inheritance by branches.

issues.text: whether notwithstanding the adoption of Ghuda Singh by his maternal uncle Bhan Singh, Ghuda Singh's descendants were not excluded from inheritance to the estate of a member in the natural family of Ghuda Singh

anchor.surface_text: It was the case of the plaintiffs that notwithstanding the adoption of Ghuda Singh by his maternal uncle Bhan Singh, Ghuda Singhs descendants were not excluded from inheritance to the estate of a member in the natural family of Ghuda Singh It was submitted by the plaintiffs that the family of the plaintiffs and Harnam Singh was governed by Zamindara Riwaj-i-am  general custom obtaining amongst the Zamindars  by virtue of which a son adopted in another family and his descendants do not lose their right to inherit in their natural family,

issues.text: whether in the District of Ferozepore every adoption in a Hindu family is formal and according to the Riwaj-i-am of the District an adopted son is excluded from the right to inherit in his natural family

anchor.surface_text: The defendants, on the other hand, claimed that in the District of Ferozepore every adoption in a Hindu family is formal and according to the Riwaj-i-am of the District an adopted son is excluded from the right to inherit in his natural family. Consequently Ghuda Singh, who was adopted by Bhan Singh, could not inherit the estate of Hamir Singh, his adoption operating as a complete severance from the natural family.

issues.text: the sole dispute between the parties was, therefore, as to the customary law applicable to the rights of a son adopted in a jat family residing in tehsil Zira, District Ferozepore

anchor.surface_text: The sole dispute between the parties was, therefore, as to the customary law applicable to the rights of a son adopted in a jat family residing in tehsil Zira, District Ferozepore. The two suits were consolidated for trial. The Subordinate judge held that all ceremonies relating to adoption were performed and Ghuda Singh ceased to be a member of the family of his natural father according to the custom prevailing in the District and the plaintiffs who were the descendants of Ghuda Singh could not inherit the estate of Hamir Singh.

issues.text: whether the adoption of Ghuda Singh made by his maternal uncle Bhan Singh was formal and in the absence of any such evidence it must be presumed that the adoption was a customary appointment of an heir and not a formal adoption under the Hindu Law

anchor.surface_text: In the view- of the High Court the record disclosed no evidence that the adoption of Ghuda Singh made by his maternal uncle Bhan Singh was formal and in the absence of any such evidence it must be presumed that the adoption was a customary appointment of an heir and not a formal adoption under the Hindu Law and that there was overwhelming authority in favour of the proposition that by reason of a customary adoption the adopted son and his descendants were not excluded from the right to inherit to collaterals in the natural family.

issues.text: the question whether there is in fact Any inconsistency between the custom recorded in Rattigans Digest of Customary Law and the relevant entries in the Riwaj-i-am

anchor.surface_text: Attention must, therefore, be directed to the question whether there is in fact Any inconsistency between the custom recorded in Rattigans Digest of Customary Law and the relevant entries in the Riwaj-i-am. The general custom recorded in Rattigans Digest is apparently this a person adopted according to the custom of the community i.e. who is appointed as an heir to inherit the property of a person outside the family does not, by virtue of such appointment, lose his right to inherit the property in his natural family except the right to -inherit the property of his natural father when there are natural brothers.

issues.text: whether there is clear evidence of instances of devolution of property in the family of the parties indicating that a son adopted in another family was totally excluded from inheritance in the natural family

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bindra contended that in any event there is clear evidence of instances of devolution of property in the family of the parties indicating that a son adopted in another family was totally excluded from inheritance in the natural family. Counsel relied upon Ext. D-5 an extract from the register of mutations

precedents.cited_proposition: Under s. 5 of Punjab Laws Act, person asserting custom must prove it; no presumption in favour of custom over personal law
precedents.cited_holding: In all cases it appears to me under this Act, it lies upon the person asserting that he is ruled in regard to a particular matter by custom, to prove that he is so governed, and number by personal law

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Hussein Khan v. Bibi Sona Dero 1 . In Vaishno Ditti v. Rameshri 2 , the ,Judicial Committee observed x x x x their Lordships are of opinion that in putting custom in the forefront,

precedents.case_name: Abdul Hussein Khan v. Bibi Sona Dero
precedents.cited_proposition: Affirmed the view on burden of proving custom under s.5 Punjab Laws Act

anchor.surface_text: Vaishno Ditti v. Rameshri 2 , the ,Judicial Committee observed x x x x their Lordships are of opinion that in putting custom in the forefront, as the rule of succession, whilst leaving the particular custom to be established,

precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature intended to recognize customs regulating inheritance departing from Hindu/Mohamedan law
precedents.cited_holding: their Lordships are of opinion that in putting custom in the forefront, as the rule of succession... the Legislature intended to recognize the fact that in this part of India inheritance... are largely regulated by a variety of customs

anchor.surface_text: Mela Singh v. Gurdas 1 , Sir Shadi Lal, C.J. observed in dealing with the effect of a customary adoption in the Punjab The tie of kinship with the natural family is number dissolved and the fiction of blood relationship with the members of the new family has numberapplication

precedents.cited_proposition: Effect of customary adoption: tie of kinship with natural family not dissolved; relationship with adoptive family purely personal
precedents.cited_holding: The tie of kinship with the natural family is number dissolved and the fiction of blood relationship with the members of the new family has numberapplication to the appointed heir. The relationship established between the appointer and the appointee, is a purely personal one

anchor.surface_text: Jagat Singh v. Ishar Singh 2 , it was held that the reservation as to the adopted son number succeeding in the presence of his brothers refers only to his succession to his natural father but does number apply to cases of companylateral succession in his natural family

precedents.cited_proposition: Adopted son does not succeed to natural father's property in presence of brothers, but can succeed collaterally in natural family

anchor.surface_text: Kanshi Ram V. Situ 3 , and Rahmat v. Ziledar 4 . In the last mentioned case it was stated Under the general custom of the province a person who is appointed as an heir to a third person does number thereby lose his right to succeed to the property of his natural father.

precedents.cited_proposition: Customary adopted son retains inheritance rights in natural family collaterally

anchor.surface_text: Rahmat v. Ziledar 4 . In the last mentioned case it was stated Under the general custom of the province a person who is appointed as an heir to a third person does number thereby lose his right to succeed to the property of his natural father. But the appointed heir and his lineal- descendants have numberright to succeed to the property of the appointed heirs natural father against the other sons of the natural father and their descendants.

precedents.cited_proposition: Appointed heir does not lose right to natural father's property against collaterals, but not against natural brothers
precedents.cited_holding: Under the general custom of the province a person who is appointed as an heir to a third person does number thereby lose his right to succeed to the property of his natural father. But the appointed heir and his lineal- descendants have numberright to succeed... against the other sons...

anchor.surface_text: In Jai Kapur v. Sher Singh 1 , it was observed There is, therefore, an initial presumption of companyrectness as regards the entries in the Riwaj-i-am and when the custom as recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in companyflict with the general custom as recorded in Rattigans Digest or ascertained otherwise, the entries in the Riwaj-i-am should ordinarily prevail

precedents.cited_proposition: Riwaj-i-am entries prevail over general custom in Rattigan's Digest in case of conflict, with initial presumption of correctness
precedents.cited_holding: There is, therefore, an initial presumption of companyrectness as regards the entries in the Riwaj-i-am... the entries in the Riwaj-i-am should ordinarily prevail

precedents.citation: Mt. Subhani v. Nawab A.I.R. 1941 P.C. 21

anchor.surface_text: the Judicial Committee in Mt. Subhani v. Nawab A.I.R. 1941 P.C. 21, that where... the Riwaj-i-am affects adversely the rights of females who had numberopportunity whatever of appearing before the revenue authorities, the presumption would be weak, and only a few instances would suffice to rebut it.

precedents.cited_proposition: Presumption from Riwaj-i-am weak where it adversely affects females' rights; few instances rebut it

anchor.surface_text: When there is conflict between the general custom stated in Rattigans Digest of Customary Law and the Riwaj-i-am which applies to a particular area it has been held by this Court that the latter prevails. We are unable to disagree with the view so expressed.

anchor.surface_text: Attention must, therefore, be directed to the question whether there is in fact Any inconsistency between the custom recorded in Rattigans Digest of Customary Law and the relevant entries in the Riwaj-i-am. The general custom recorded in Rattigans Digest is apparently this a person adopted according to the custom of the community i.e. who is appointed as an heir to inherit the property of a person outside the family does number, by virtue of such appointment, lose his right to inherit the property in his natural family except the right to -inherit the property of his natural father when there are natural brothers.
We are unable to disagree with the view so expressed.

But we are number companycerned with that inconsistency in this case. It is sufficient to observe that in Art. 48 of Rattigans Digest, it is recorded that an heir appointed in the manner described  an adopted son  does number thereby lose his right to succeed to property in his natural family
We are unable to disagree with the view so expressed.
